[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: new_oracle_provider_config()] [Default Handling] If oracle::config creates OracleProviderConfig instances with default values (empty pair_id, enable=false), can these invalid configs accidentally be activated, causing oracle queries to fail? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: supra_provider()] [String Bounds] ASCII strings may have length limits - if a provider name is too long, can string operations fail in ways that allow an attacker to inject truncated names that bypass validation? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Module: oracle_provider] [Registry Design] There's no central registry of valid providers - can attackers create arbitrary OracleProvider instances that the system treats as legitimate if they pass basic structure checks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: new_oracle_provider_config()] [Friend Visibility] All mutation functions are friend-only, but read functions are public - can attackers use public reads to probe the oracle configuration state and time attacks based on observed configs? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: new_oracle_provider_config()] [Validation Missing] No validation that provider, enable, and pair_id form a coherent configuration - can attackers create nonsensical configs (e.g., supra_provider with Pyth pair_id format) that cause runtime errors? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Module: oracle_provider] [Fallback Handling] If all providers have enable=false, how does the system behave? Can an attacker disable all providers to force the system to use stale prices or halt operations? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Struct: OracleProvider] [Copy Semantics] OracleProvider has copy ability - if an attacker copies a provider and modifies its name in memory (if possible through other vulnerabilities), can this cause provider confusion in oracle routing? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: get_pair_id_from_oracle_provider_config()] [Format Assumptions] Different oracle providers may use different pair_id formats (Pyth uses 32-byte hex, Supra may use different encoding) - if consuming code doesn't handle format differences, can this cause lookup failures? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: is_oracle_provider_config_enable()] [Race Condition] If one transaction checks is_oracle_provider_config_enable() and another concurrently calls set_enable_to_oracle_provider_config(), can the first transaction proceed with stale enable state, using an oracle that should be disabled? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Module: oracle_provider] [Uniqueness Enforcement] There's no mechanism to ensure provider names are unique - can multiple configs with the same provider name but different settings cause oracle queries to return inconsistent results? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: is_empty()] [Null Safety] The is_empty check only tests name length - if other parts of the system assume empty providers are never used but don't check is_empty(), can empty providers bypass safety checks? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Struct: OracleProviderConfig] [Lifetime Management] OracleProviderConfig has store but no key - if stored in shared objects without proper cleanup, can stale configs persist indefinitely and affect oracle selection logic? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_provider.move] [Function: to_string()] [Name Injection] If provider names are used in error messages or logs without sanitization, can attackers craft names with control characters or escape sequences to manipulate logging/monitoring systems? (Low)
